G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19 & 19A.proposition: This Court has subject-matter jurisdiction over this civil action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 & 19A, and G.L. c. 212, § 3, in that the claims asserted are civil claims sounding in negligence and the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has subject-matter jurisdiction over this civil action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 & 19A, and G.L. c. 212, § 3, in that the claims asserted are civil claims sounding in negligence and the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2, and 8.proposition: Venue is proper in the Brockton District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, and 8 because the cause of action arose in Brockton, Massachusetts, and Defendant conducts business and operates the subject premises in Brockton.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a person or entity that undertakes the care and supervision of a child owes that child a duty to exercise reasonable care in all circumstances, including a duty to provide adequate supervision and to protect the child from reasonably foreseeable harm.

Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47, 449 N.E.2d 331 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a person or entity that undertakes the care and supervision of a child owes that child a duty to exercise reasonable care in all circumstances, including a duty to provide adequate supervision and to protect the child from reasonably foreseeable harm.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..support_reasoning: This excerpt is a dissent focused entirely on proximate cause, not on the existence or scope of a duty to supervise or protect a child (or student). While Mullins v. Pine Manor College as a whole is well-known for recognizing a college’s duty to exercise reasonable care to protect resident students from foreseeable criminal acts, the quoted portion does not discuss or establish that duty; it assumes duty and contests causation. Thus, this particular opinion text does not itself support the stated proposition about duty of care and supervision.
Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “In my opinion the plaintiff failed to introduce sufficient evidence to warrant a finding that action or inaction of the defendants was the proximate cause of her injury, and the defendants were entitled to directed verdicts and judgments in their favor.”

Irwin v. Town of Ware, 392 Mass. 745, 46.raw_text: Irwin v. Town of Ware, 392 Mass. 745, 468 N.E.2d 1292 (1984)
Irwin v. Town of Ware, 392 Mass. 745, 46.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a person or entity that undertakes the care and supervision of a child owes that child a duty to exercise reasonable care in all circumstances, including a duty to provide adequate supervision and to protect the child from reasonably foreseeable harm.
Irwin v. Town of Ware, 392 Mass. 745, 46.support_reasoning: The case recognizes that entities (including public ones) can owe affirmative duties of reasonable care based on ‘special relationships,’ and it specifically holds that a town may be liable for police officers’ negligent failure to protect members of the motoring public from a drunk driver. However, the opinion does not address the general rule for all persons or entities that undertake the care and supervision of a child, nor does it discuss child supervision or custodial relationships with children. Its holding is about police duties to the public regarding intoxicated drivers, not about a general Massachusetts duty owed by caretakers of children.
Irwin v. Town of Ware, 392 Mass. 745, 46.relevant_excerpt: “A duty to act with reasonable care to prevent harm to a plaintiff which, if violated, may give rise to tort liability is based on a ‘special relationship’ between the plaintiff and the defendant…. While several different categories of such special relationships are recognized in the common law, they are based to a large extent on a uniform set of considerations. Foremost among these is whether a defendant reasonably could foresee that he would be expected to take affirmative action to protect the plaintiff and could anticipate harm to the plaintiff from the failure to do so.”

Mullins, 389 Mass. at 52\u201355.proposition: Defendant, by operating an after-school program for children and inviting Plaintiff’s Minor Child to participate, undertook a custodial and supervisory role and thereby owed a duty of reasonable care to Plaintiff’s Minor Child.

Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.raw_text: Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mass. 37, 907 N.E.2d 213 (2009)
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.proposition: Defendant, by operating an after-school program for children and inviting Plaintiff’s Minor Child to participate, undertook a custodial and supervisory role and thereby owed a duty of reasonable care to Plaintiff’s Minor Child.
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.support_reasoning: The case does not involve an after-school program, children, or a voluntarily assumed custodial/supervisory role over a minor. Instead, it concerns whether a hospital owed a duty to an unrelated third-party police officer based on its handling of a sedated adult patient, and the court expressly rejects expanding duties to third parties on theories of special relationship or voluntary assumption. Nothing in the opinion suggests that merely operating a program and inviting participation creates a custodial duty analogous to that asserted in the proposition.
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “We have not previously recognized, and do not now recognize, a duty to a third person of a medical professional to control a patient (excluding a patient of a mental health professional, see note 10, supra) arising from any claimed special relationship between the medical professional and the patient. … The hospital owed no duty to Leavitt to control or detain the patient.”

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 706, 2.proposition: Defendant, as the operator of a place of public accommodation and a recreational facility, further owed a duty to maintain its premises and activities in a reasonably safe condition and to take reasonable steps to prevent foreseeable injuries to children lawfully present.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 706, 2.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Mounsey v. Ellard is a concurrence focused on abolishing the invitee/licensee distinction and questioning the treatment of trespassers. It does not discuss operators of public accommodations or recreational facilities, nor does it articulate a specific heightened duty toward children lawfully present. While the broader case deals with occupiers’ liability generally, this excerpt does not clearly support the specific proposition about duties of a recreational facility to children.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 706, 2.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a 'licensee' rather than an 'invitee,' or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that 'trespassers' stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential. This tends to perpetuate, although on a smaller scale, the kind of tradition-bound and mistaken analysis that I had supposed the court was aiming to correct."

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.raw_text: Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739, 652 N.E.2d 567 (1995)
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.proposition: Defendant, as the operator of a place of public accommodation and a recreational facility, further owed a duty to maintain its premises and activities in a reasonably safe condition and to take reasonable steps to prevent foreseeable injuries to children lawfully present.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.support_reasoning: The case is about the scope of a landowner’s duty with respect to an adjacent state highway and ultimately holds that the racetrack had no duty to alter the highway. However, in reaching that conclusion the court expressly reaffirms the general common-law rule that an owner or possessor of land owes lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care, including maintaining the premises in reasonably safe condition and warning of unreasonable dangers. That general duty is consistent with the proposition about a public accommodation/recreational facility’s obligation to keep its premises and activities reasonably safe for patrons, including children lawfully present, even though children and public-accommodation status are not specifically discussed.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. … This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.” 420 Mass. at 742-43.

Mullins, 389 Mass. at 54\u201355.proposition: Defendant knew or should have known that children, particularly older boys, may engage in roughhousing and physically risky behavior in a gym setting, and that younger and smaller children are particularly vulnerable to injury in such circumstances.

Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.raw_text: Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 378 N.E.2d 995 (1978)
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.proposition: Defendant knew or should have known that children, particularly older boys, may engage in roughhousing and physically risky behavior in a gym setting, and that younger and smaller children are particularly vulnerable to injury in such circumstances.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns premises liability and foreseeability relating to unsecured forklifts and intoxicated seamen; it does not involve children, gyms, roughhousing, or comparative vulnerability of younger/smaller children. The foreseeability analysis here is about unauthorized operation of dangerous machinery by intoxicated adults and resulting injury to visitors, not behavioral tendencies of children in a recreational or gym setting. Using this case to support the stated proposition about knowledge of children’s roughhousing in a gym would mischaracterize its holding and context.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.relevant_excerpt: "Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable. The authority had specific procedures for securing the forklifts whether or not the 'C & D shed' was locked. The forklift, which had an unusual steering system, could be dangerous when operated by an unskilled driver. The authority was aware that intoxicated seamen frequented the area, and it was also aware that social guests of officers or crew members routinely visited the ships in port."

Kelley v. Rossi, 395 Mass. 659, 481 N.E..proposition: Defendant’s personnel policies, training, supervision of its own staff, and day-to-day practices were inadequate and unreasonable in light of the known risks associated with children at play in a gym environment.
Kelley v. Rossi, 395 Mass. 659, 481 N.E..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a resident physician was a “public employee” under the Massachusetts Tort Claims Act and thus immune from suit, focusing on control, direction, and borrowed‑servant status. It does not address institutional liability for inadequate personnel policies, training, supervision, or day‑to‑day practices, nor does it involve risks associated with children playing in a gym or any similar environment. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the proposition about unreasonable policies and supervision in a child‑gym context.
Kelley v. Rossi, 395 Mass. 659, 481 N.E..relevant_excerpt: “Our task on appeal is to determine whether, on the material properly before the judge on the motion for summary judgment, there was no genuine issue of material fact as to the doctor’s claim that she was an employee of the city of Boston or one of its agencies… The legal principles that govern the determination whether the doctor was a ‘public employee’ of the city… are the same as those that have determined whether an agent is a servant for whose negligent acts a principal may be liable under the common law doctrine of respondeat superior.”

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 723 N..proposition: Defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of care that a reasonably prudent operator of an after-school program and youth recreation facility in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts would exercise under similar circumstances.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 723 N..support_reasoning: The case does not involve an after-school program or youth recreation facility, nor does it articulate or apply any standard of care specific to such operators. Instead, it concerns a homeowner/general contractor liability issue on a residential roofing project and ultimately affirms summary judgment for the defendant due to lack of proof of causation (and uncertainty about duty/control), without defining a particular standard of care. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the claimed Massachusetts standard for after-school program operators.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 723 N..relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs argue that they presented sufficient evidence to warrant a trial of each of their negligence claims. With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. … The plaintiffs also produced no evidence tending to show that the defendant knew or should have known of any hazardous condition on his building.”

Mullins, 389 Mass. at 54\u201356.proposition: Had Defendant maintained adequate staffing, actively supervised the children, responded promptly to complaints about rough play, prohibited tackle-style games on the hard floor, and separated older and younger children, the dangerous situation would have been corrected, and the incident and resulting injuries to Plaintiff’s Minor Child would, more likely than not, have been prevented.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 849 N.E.2d.proposition: Had Defendant maintained adequate staffing, actively supervised the children, responded promptly to complaints about rough play, prohibited tackle-style games on the hard floor, and separated older and younger children, the dangerous situation would have been corrected, and the incident and resulting injuries to Plaintiff’s Minor Child would, more likely than not, have been prevented.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 849 N.E.2d.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns whether, with adequate staffing and active supervision of children, prompt response to rough play complaints, restrictions on tackle-style games, and age separation, an incident on a hard floor would more likely than not have been prevented. Jupin v. Kask addresses a homeowner’s duty and foreseeability related to negligent storage of firearms and access by a violent, mentally unstable adult, not supervision or safety protocols in a child-play or childcare setting. It provides no discussion of staffing levels, supervision of children, or prevention of rough play, so it does not support the claimed proposition.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 849 N.E.2d.relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. … In the circumstances of this case, we conclude that a homeowner who permits guns to be stored on her property and allows unsupervised access to that property by a person known by her to have a history of violence and mental instability, has a duty of reasonable care to ensure that the guns are properly secured.”

Jesionek, 376 Mass. at 105.proposition: The harm suffered by Plaintiff’s Minor Child—injury from being tackled and striking his head during rough, unsupervised play in a gym—was a reasonably foreseeable consequence of Defendant’s failure to exercise due care in supervising the children.
Jesionek, 376 Mass. at 105.support_reasoning: Jesionek concerns an adult plaintiff injured when an intoxicated seaman operated an unsecured forklift; the foreseeability analysis is about leaving a dangerous instrumentality unsecured in an area frequented by intoxicated seamen and visitors. It does not involve children, supervision of children, rough or unsupervised play, or the duty to supervise in a school or recreational setting. While it is relevant to general principles of foreseeability and intervening acts, it does not specifically support the proposition about foreseeability of harm from rough, unsupervised play in a gym due to negligent supervision of children.
Jesionek, 376 Mass. at 105.relevant_excerpt:
Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable. The authority had specific procedures for securing the forklifts whether or not the "C & D shed" was locked. The forklift, which had an unusual steering system, could be dangerous when operated by an unskilled driver. The authority was aware that intoxicated seamen frequented the area, and it was also aware that social guests of officers or crew members routinely visited the ships in port.

It was thus reasonably foreseeable that the forklift, when left unsecured with the keys in the ignition on premises which were solely under the authority’s control, would be operated by unauthorized persons...

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637, 671 N.E.2d 156 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: The harm suffered by Plaintiff’s Minor Child—injury from being tackled and striking his head during rough, unsupervised play in a gym—was a reasonably foreseeable consequence of Defendant’s failure to exercise due care in supervising the children.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: The concurrence explicitly agrees that the plaintiff’s injuries were not within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by the defendant’s negligence. That is the opposite of the claimed proposition, which asserts that the child’s injury was a reasonably foreseeable consequence of inadequate supervision. Thus, this opinion undermines rather than supports the stated proposition.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 43.raw_text: Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 437 N.E.2d 171 (1982)
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 43.proposition: Plaintiff’s Minor Child endured physical pain, emotional distress, anxiety, and mental suffering arising from the incident and the resulting injury and medical treatment.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 43.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a minor child’s recovery for physical pain and emotional distress from an incident, injury, and medical treatment. Payton v. Abbott Labs addresses whether Massachusetts allows recovery for negligent infliction of emotional distress absent physical harm and sets out requirements for such claims, but it does not discuss a minor child’s specific damages of physical pain, emotional distress, anxiety, and mental suffering from an injury and medical care. The case is about DES-exposed daughters’ emotional-distress claims and prenatal injury, not about the scope of a child’s pain-and-suffering damages from a discrete injury and its treatment, so it does not support the proposition as stated.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 43.relevant_excerpt: “In summary, we hold that a plaintiff in order to recover for negligently inflicted emotional distress must prove the following: (1) negligence; (2) emotional distress; (3) causation; (4) physical harm manifested by objective symptomatology; and (5) that a reasonable person would have suffered emotional distress under the circumstances of the case.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B, Plaintiff is also entitled to prejudgment interest on the amount of his damages from the date of commencement of this action.

Sorensen v. Sorensen, 369 Mass. 350, 339.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a parent may recover for medical expenses reasonably incurred on behalf of a minor child as a result of the child’s injuries.
Sorensen v. Sorensen, 369 Mass. 350, 339.support_reasoning: The opinion is about abrogating parental immunity to permit an unemancipated minor to sue a parent in tort for automobile negligence, not about a parent’s separate right to recover medical expenses incurred for a child. The only reference to medical expenses is that the minor plaintiff herself sought them as an element of damages, which is different from recognizing a parent’s independent claim. The case therefore does not establish that a parent may recover medical expenses on behalf of an injured minor child under Massachusetts law.
Sorensen v. Sorensen, 369 Mass. 350, 339.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff, an unemancipated minor, brought this action by her mother and next friend, Linda Sorensen, to recover for personal injuries… The plaintiff also sought recovery for ‘conscious suffering’ and medical expenses.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85M.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a parent may recover for medical expenses reasonably incurred on behalf of a minor child as a result of the child’s injuries.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85 (1).proposition: Plaintiff and his Minor Child are entitled to recover all damages reasonably flowing from Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to: medical expenses, pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, and any other cognizable damages under Massachusetts law.

doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.raw_text: doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776, 328 N.E.2d 873 (1975)
doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.proposition: Plaintiff and his Minor Child are entitled to recover all damages reasonably flowing from Defendant’s negligence, including but not limited to: medical expenses, pain and suffering, loss of enjoyment of life, and any other cognizable damages under Massachusetts law.
doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses liability issues, duty to warn, design negligence, consortium, and excessiveness of a jury award, but it does not articulate any rule about the categories of damages recoverable (such as medical expenses, pain and suffering, or loss of enjoyment of life) or about the scope of damages ‘reasonably flowing’ from negligence. The brief damages discussion is only in the context of reviewing a verdict for excessiveness, not as a statement of governing legal principles for all plaintiffs or minor children under Massachusetts law. Accordingly, the case does not serve as authority for the specific proposition about recoverable damages categories.
doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.relevant_excerpt: In concluding that the judge committed no error of law, we consider Ezila’s age (twenty-nine) and weekly earnings ($140) at the time of the accident; the loss of ninety-five per cent of the function of her right hand (her dominant hand); her inability to perform many household tasks or to obtain employment; her pain and suffering, particularly while her hand was in the machine and while she was in the hospital... Although many of these elements of damage are incapable of precise, monetary measurement, the trial judge... is in a far better position than we to determine the reasonableness of the jury’s award.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85 (2).proposition: No act or omission by Plaintiff or his Minor Child constituted negligence that was greater than the negligence of Defendant, and to the extent any comparative negligence is alleged, Plaintiff invokes the protections of G.L. c. 231, § 85, which provides that contributory negligence does not bar recovery if the plaintiff’s negligence was not greater than that of the defendant, and that any damages shall be diminished in proportion to the amount of negligence attributable to the plaintiff.

G.L. c. 261.proposition: Award Plaintiff his taxable costs of this action pursuant to G.L. c. 261 and applicable rules;
